Dos and Dont’s

What are some use cases designers should pay attention to? Describe the do’s and dont’s for each particular use case. You can also use this section as a catch-all for guidance that can’t fit into other sections.

Truncation

Use clear, simple label names

Do not truncate labels or drop labels to a second line. If your label is too long, work with a content designer to identify a better label.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

Write some general guidelines around the accessibility of the component. These could be principles for usage, the accessibility goal of the component, or some tips.
Place any pertinent WCAG references here as well.
Example: ”It is also important to avoid designing alerts that disappear automatically. An alert that disappears too quickly can lead to failure to meet WCAG 2.0 success criterion 2.2.3.”
Check out W3C for a quick idea on potential WCAG 2.0 references.
Also, check out Control Hub’s Accessibility Specs and leverage any content there.

Select filter

Select accessibility involves designing dropdown menus that are easy to use and understandable for people with disabilities. Key considerations include providing clear and concise labels, ensuring sufficient contrast, enabling keyboard accessibility, providing focus indicators, offering autocomplete suggestions or search filters, and ensuring clear error messages. By addressing these elements, designers can create dropdown menus that are inclusive and accessible to all users.

Keyboard Navigation

To navigate a Select, use a Tab stop to navigate between elements. Keyboard interactions for select/filter fields include:

Element
Purpose

Tab

Moves focus to next interactive element

Shift

+

Tab

Moves focus back to the previous interactive element

Enter

Selects a list item and then closes the dropdown menu

Space

Selects a list item and then closes the dropdown menu

Esc

/

Tab

Closes the dropdown menu without committing to a selection

Up Arrow

Moves the selection within the dropdown menu list items

Home

/

End

Moves the selection to the first or last item in a dropdown menu respectively

Keyboard interactions (Input Chips)

Controls

OR

To move focus to next element.

Screen Reader

Selet filter

The Select screen reader must inform a user of at least the following, normally in this order:

Name - visible label OR screen reader text
Current option value
State - required, read-only, disabled, etc.
Menu state - collapsed or opened

Screen readers may not read placeholder text. Screen reader output can vary significantly depending on the user’s web browser and other factors, so to accommodate screen reader users, you should always include a static label.
The following are the announcement orders:

Dropdown Select

Visible Label
Structural Role
Functional Role
Functional Role
Announcement

Headquarters location

Combobox

Combo box, Headquarters location
Select your headquarters location
